title: As Venezuela’s Politicians Fight Over Aid, Patients Die Without It
abstract: The opposition has vowed to deliver food and medication, but the president has refused to allow it. Patients whose lives depend on aid fear the political standoff is obscuring their desperate crisis.
byline: By ANATOLY KURMANAEV and ISAYEN HERRERA
org_facet: United States Agency for International Development

multimedia.caption: Nora Elicsa Casique, 8, in the intensive care unit of Central Hospital in San Cristóbal, Venezuela. She fractured her skull and right leg when the motorcycle she was riding on was struck by a truck. Her father has been hunting for medical supplies in pharmacies, on the black market and in Colombia.
multimedia.copyright: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times

title: The Vatican Is Talking About Clerical Abuse, but Italy Isn’t. Here’s Why.
abstract: While other countries have taken a hard look at the abuse of children by priests, Italy’s approach has been something closer to a media blackout.

multimedia.caption: Gianni Bisoli, 69, said he was abused by priests when he was a pupil at the Antonio Provolo Institute, a Catholic school for the deaf in Verona, Italy. “The pope talks and talks, but doesn’t do anything,” he said of the clerical abuse scandal.
multimedia.copyright: Francesca Volpi for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Gianni Bisoli, 69, said he was abused by priests when he was a pupil at the Antonio Provolo Institute, a Catholic school for the deaf in Verona, Italy. “The pope talks and talks, but doesn’t do anything,” he said of the clerical abuse scandal.

title: For Yemen Child Soldiers, a Refuge Mixes Play With Saudi Propaganda
abstract: A Saudi-financed center offers six weeks of comfort and schooling to former child soldiers in Yemen. But it doubles as a propaganda stage set, blaming only one side for the conflict: Houthis.

multimedia.caption: A child’s drawing of a battle scene, right, at the Saudi-financed rehabilitation center for child soldiers. At left, a child in red identifies himself on a hill, facing his enemy on the other hill.

title: South Korea Awaits 2nd Kim-Trump Summit With Both Hope and Fear
abstract: More than anyone else, President Moon Jae-in hopes that President Trump and Kim Jong-un will agree on denuclearizing North Korea when they meet in Vietnam this month.

byline: By ANA VANESSA HERRERO and NICHOLAS CASEY

abstract: As another party lawmaker left for an independent grouping, leaders struggled to combat charges that Labour is “institutionally anti-Semitic.”

title: India Threatens a New Weapon Against Pakistan: Water
abstract: India vowed to reduce the amount of water flowing through its rivers to Pakistan, a threat it has made before but now seems more determined to carry out because of a militant attack.

multimedia.caption: Baglihar Dam on the Chenab River, which flows from India-controlled Kashmir into Pakistan. A water war could be catastrophic to the hundreds of millions of people in India and Pakistan who depend on river water.

title: In Beirut, a ‘Teeming Vision of the Inferno’

title: Maduro Closes Venezuela’s Border With Brazil to Block Aid
abstract: The closure is part of Mr. Maduro’s effort to foil plans by his opponents to bring in humanitarian supplies, including food and medication, by force.

multimedia.caption: President Nicolás Maduro ordered Venezuela’s border with Brazil closed on Thursday.

title: How Israel’s Moon Lander Got to the Launchpad
abstract: With $100 million and a lot of volunteer labor, SpaceIL’s Beresheet spacecraft could be the first privately built vessel to reach the lunar surface.

multimedia.caption: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket with Israel’s Lunar Lander and an Indonesian communications satellite launched on Thursday in Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Scores Dead in Bangladesh Fire: ‘This Isn’t About Poverty, It’s About Greed’
abstract: The inferno, which was set off when a car’s gas cylinder exploded, ravaged one of the most historic neighborhoods in Bangladesh, a country with a horrible record of deadly fires.
